review_title: AV Integration Project Management and Design
pros:
With a new(ish) VC some changes are starting to happen which could make ARU a better place to work. 

The working atmosphere in the university is not the best it has been....
cons: ARU is not the best place for opportunities or career progression, plus the university is not great on its salary scales either, with little to no chance of pay scale movement.

pros: ARU is diverse and developing in exciting new ways. It is welcoming to people from all walks of life and the art school facilities are open to all students in the school, encouraging collaboration. The facilities are managed by the technical team, who have ownership over each of their specialist areas.
cons: Sometimes it is difficult to find who the right person is to help with a question or find the answer to questions in the university systems. There are multiple platforms which can cause confusion.

job_title: Head of Solution Development in Chelmsford, England
pros:
I love ARU. I grew up there, learned everything from the brilliant people I worked with over the years, and have a genuine affection that will remain with me forever.

ARU's top-performing staff are true industry exemplars, with a work ethic and dedication to rival any industry.

ARU's student demographic is inspiring in so many ways, not least because the typical demographic is less privileged than you would find at most other universities.

When times are good, they are very, very good.

---

ARU is the lovable oaf you traditionally invite to your Christmas dinner. A few rough edges, but we forgive them that because, well, they're family, and they're from a different time, and they probably don't mean it in quite the way they said it, and anyway, it's Christmas time - it's a time for giving, a time for getting; a time for forgiving, and for forgetting. (Cliff Richard, 1988)
cons:
Whilst ARU's best staff are among the best in the country, ARU's average staff performance is unacceptable in most industry circumstances.

ARU's commitment to staff welfare and mental wellness is genuine, but local implementation is patchy at best.

ARU's IT strategy is outmoded and poorly-managed, leading to impossible timescales and folly projects.

Direction and leadership is highly reactive rather than controlled and strategic, leading to a stressful working environment and poor staff satisfaction.

---

ARU is the lovable oaf you are compelled to maintain a relationship with over the Christmas dinner for fear of rocking long-standing family traditions. They are not as well-informed as they think they are, making an honest discussion an improbability. They do indeed come from a different time with intentions that started out well, but in recent years they started mixing with the wrong people and believing the wrong truths. They conflate strength of character with strength of argument, and that way madness lies. You can't help but admire their conviction, but worry about their chosen direction.

pros: Flexible, agile working, work from home, good pension, very nice colleagues

review_title: Nice job to have on the side of your studies
pros:
Working on an ad-hoc basis, mostly at open days/evenings and student events - it works if you're a busy student (or have work hour limitations if you're on a student visa). 

Nice pay and always a great, helping team and management (and free ARU t-shirts/hoodies). 

It was helpful to network with other students and lecturers, and you generally get to learn more about the university and its services and facilities.
cons: The ad-hoc basis might not be stable enough for some as you're only working a few times a month, so can't expect to earn a lot.

pros: Good colleagues and atmosphere. Well paid
cons: Hard work, very stressful, too corporate and too much pressure on teachers

review_title: Friendly place to work and great team spirit
pros: A friendly, welcoming place to work, a recent staff survey showed. Good at diversity and inclusion and people generally enjoy working here, especially feeling supported by their line manager and immediate team. New VC is really impressive and I feel hopeful that the changes he is making will make ARU a better place to work.
cons: Sometimes there is a mismatch between the intention to put staff first and what happens in practice. You are expected to work hard but don't always feel this is recognised or rewarded.  Awful systems and staff have been home-working for almost a year using their own equipment - shocking!

job_title: Receptionist Web Editor in Cambridge, England
pros: Very nice environment of work
cons: Nice people, nice hours, nice salary

pros:
I joined AR University in September 2016 as a member of academic staff, and by far I am fully pleased and satisfied with my work here. 

Interview went excellent, very friendly and supportive atmosphere, 5 out of 5. Fast and efficient recruitment process.
On my first working day  I received all the essential instructions, little tour across campus, and timetable with all important deadlines. 

Some of the advantages:

1) Excellent corporate culture, diverse community of colleagues, relaxed creative atmosphere. I don't experience ANY stress at work (which is brilliant!!).
2) Good location of the campus (Chelmsford, LAIBS, 40 min from London).
3) Good restaurant at the ground floor with very friendly staff. Good quality of food too. 
4) Good IT support, very fast.
5) Modern classrooms and other university facilities.
6) Excellent admin team, always friendly and supportive. 
7) Good teaching/research/admin work balance;
8) Faculty supported my research a lot. Just within 6 months of my employment, they approved the purchase of the individual licence for research software, sponsored the overseas trip for international research conference. 
9) Support for professional development. (e.g. PG cert Learning and Teaching Higher Education, and other trainings/workshops).
cons: so far so good, have not anything in mind.

pros: Excellent location (Cambridge); salaries are fair; good career progression.
cons:
Poor management is common at ARU (unfortunately) - heads of department / faculty are usually people who should never be a manager - they just have such aspirations (but not the skills / experience) and unfortunately this university allow them to be there... 

Lack of research culture - it's all about pleasing the students to keep them happy with eyes on their money - £9250 per year it's a lot and honestly it's not worthwhile here (or maybe in any public university - if they are public why do students have to pay a fortune to study? most of jobs they will get after graduation will worth more than £15000 a year...

pros: The campus locations are great. The work load is varied and interesting. The majority of people who work there are warm and friendly.
cons: If the management staff worked as hard as they do to make sure that "they" are not to blame for mistakes as they do general working so much could be achieved by this university. Management appears to be from the 70's with its attitude to how it treats its staff. Little or no regards to a work life balance (you work for us first then home life second - no matter what). Hours can be long with little or no encouragement for the work you do. ARU is not great on its salary scales either, with little chance of pay scale movement.

job_title: Junior Research Fellow in Cambridge, England
pros:
It's great to be [art of an institution that's improving. 
There are good development opportunities for research staff. 
My head of dept is wonderful, very supportive.
cons: Workload can be unrealistic for full time lecturing staff. Many Anglia students require additional contact time in order to pass. This is never accounted for in workload balancing.

review_title: What is wrong with current contract
pros: there is somehow good communication with staff. I am really struggling with this as it was a short collaboration and it was mainly negative.
cons:
Paid to do a seminar and marking. 
Claims can't be done until all is completed, meaning you've to hang in for a couple of months before being paid. 
you can't claim for travel expenses
the marking is ridiculous: you're paid to mark 6 (SIX!) essays per hour. which makes it something like 2 pounds per essay. How is one supposed to read everything and give any type of constructve and useful feedback in 10 minutes?

pros: Great team, a good place to be for a short period of time. Very friendly. Good CV experience from working with students and members of the general public. Good exposure on external communications with contractors. Made lots of good contacts with the rest of the University. Great flow of work.
cons: The office is small. During hand in days the queue was reaching 20 meters. Needs more room, staff and space to cope with the volume of work.

pros: Location,good transport, shopping, proximity to train station.
cons: Management attitude is exploitative, useless fast-tracked management without any people management experience. Disgusting attitude towards part-time lecturers who do all hard work but are treated poorly, with no career progression and threatened with sack if they do not want to teach subjects they are given. Management is amateurish, cliquish, full of misandrists and feminists, commercially naive, spiteful staff, science backwater, location. Full time staff are lazy in research and having all sort of excuse for flexible workign and not being in the office actually doing work they are paid for. To sum it up, awful place to work!

review_title: Easy job, Monday to Friday, no bad salary
pros: Good staff working in catering. Very good shift (7.30am-3.30pm) from Mon to Fri although sometimes you are required to work extra hours on Saturday or after work. Breakfast and lunch food free.
cons: The people working there for long time are too bossy. Extra hours not paid, you get just lieu time instead.

job_title: Business Relationship Manager in Cambridge, England
pros:
It is a good organisation and delivers a very good service.
The IT infrastructure is relatively up-to-date with some very effective technology.
There is an IT strategy in place aligned with the Faculties and Support Services.
cons: As you would expect in a University there is a lot of bureaucracy and so it takes a while to decide to act, however when decisions are made, they are clearly agreed and progress can then be made.

Bureaucracy, line managers not approving training even though staff is encouraged to take up training from higher up. 
I was an administrator very keen to progress, but was not encouraged and empowered. Never got enough work even though I kept asking for more.
